meanings.definition: To suggest or hint at indirectly.
meanings.sent1: She impled that she wanted to leave early by repeatedly checking the time.
meanings.sent2: The teacher impled that there would be a pop quiz by giving extra homework.
meanings.sent3: His sly smile impled mischief was afoot.
meanings.sent4: The dark clouds impled an approaching storm.
meanings.sent5: The detective's raised eyebrow impled he had a lead on the case.

meanings.definition: To involve or imply without explicitly stating.
meanings.sent1: The new policy impled changes to the company's structure.
meanings.sent2: His silence impled guilt in the eyes of the jury.
meanings.sent3: The empty chair impled someone was missing from the meeting.
meanings.sent4: The broken window impled a break-in had occurred.
meanings.sent5: The unfinished puzzle impled pieces were lost.
